section.title: Introduction
section.para: When Joel Spolsky ("Joel on Software") wrote his notorious blog post "Language Wars", many people asked whether he has "jumped the shark" and that his blog will go downhill from there. I too have read the post, and agreed, that while it had a few good points, it was too based on "feeling rather than knowing". Joel later on posted many good articles and shorter entries on his blog, but many people still recallled it as a very low-point in the blog.

Like Joel, I have a home-site and several blogs, where I post articles and essays about my thoughts, and this time I've decided to risk something similar to what Joel has done on an equally flamatory topic: licences of open-source software. I'm going to introduce the various options, explain a little about their history and motivation and then give some advice according to my own personal opinion.

I should note that I am not a lawyer, and only write this according to my best knowledge, understanding and experience.
Some people believe that discussing legal matters should be reserved to people who are Law experts. However, this is a sub-case of the "only specialists should deal with a specialised field" fallacy.
Like it or not, the Law affects us all and the Government expects common citizens to be aware of it and not violate it, even if they are not lawyers. As software developers, we do not limit discussions on software and computing to people with a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science (much less a Ph.D. or whatever) and often not-too-qualified people can be very knowledgable and/or productive.
Similarly, I expect discussions on the governmental law to have a lower barrier for entry than people who are qualified lawyers, or Law Professors.
I think what I'm writing here is correct, but would still appreciate any correction for future versions. If you're unsure about my advice, then my advice to you is to consult a legal expert (if you can afford one) or your local or global Free and Open Source Software organisation. I cannot guarantee my advice is valid.

section.title: Spoiler
section.para: In this spoiler I'll explain what I'm using right away, which is also what I recommend other people to use. When I started releasing my code as open-source software, I used the Public Domain. So, for example, Freecell Solver which is one of my earliest projects and still one of the most successful, still carries a COPYING file with the following contents:

blockquote.para: Relax, this is not GPL software, but rather it is distributed under the public domain. It means it can be linked against anything, converted to any different license, freely used and distributed, and anything else without any restrictions whatsoever. No Strings Attached!â„¢

section.para: (This was also a joke of sorts.)

Later on, to avoid the problematic status of public domain code in many countries, and to avoid other potential legal problems, I started distributing my original code under the MIT X11 Licence, a BSD-style licence which is the closest one to the Public Domain. If the project I'm contributing to has a different licence, then I disclaim any explicit or implicit ownership on the code I wrote, and allow the existing copyright holders to do with my code as they see fit.

Note that I'm using different terms for other types of digital artworks. Most of my essays (including this one) are under the Creative Commons Attribution Licence, my original (i.e: non-derived-work or fan-art) fictitious stories are under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike Licence (which is more GPL-like), and most of the photos I took and published were placed under the Public Domain.

section.title: History and Overview of Common Licences
In the Beginning - there was the Public Domain
section.para: As computers became more popular after World War II, people started writing software for them and sometimes distributing it. This software written in Machine code, Assembly, or more portable high-level programming languages, enabled people other than the original author to run the code and make use of it. The traditional "licence" for such software was the Public Domain, which is a legal term in the United States and other countries that describes what becomes of an intellectual artwork whose (limited) copyright term has expired. As traditionally understood, a Public Domain artwork can be freely distributed (commercially or non-commercially), freely derived from and included in future artworks, and freely used and enjoyed. As a result, such software was generally free-for-all-to-use.

That's not all. In fact, as many computer workers at that point in hisotry understood, it was unnaturaly for software to be copyrighted and be under any licence besides the Public Domain. Evidence for this can be found in Bill Gates' "Open Letter to (Altair) Hobbyists", where he expressed dismay on them contacting him about copying his company's version of BASIC for the Altair (an early home computer), instead of buying it for money.

Non-public-domain software (from now on "proprietary" or "non-free" software) actually preceded Gates, and was common on mainframe (LINK) or mini-computers (LINK), which were the very big (and in today's standards' - incredibly under-equiped) computers that preceded the now common microprocessor-based. However, there was still a strong tradition of what we now called open-source software back then. See for example, the SHARE group that shared software for IBM-based computers.

section.title: AT&T UNIX, BSD, and the BSD Licence
section.para: The original UNIX was an operating system originally created by AT&T's Bell Labs Workers for Digital Equipment Corporation's (LINK) PDP-11 (LINK) computers, based on earlier efforts, which was distributed along with its source code in the C programming language to interested parties across the world.

One of the hallmarks of AT&T UNIX was that despite the fact that its source code was not fully-open-source (see below) in today's standards, it was still a fully functional operating system distributed along with its source, which rapidly gained popularity.

Eventually, several workers in the University of California in Berkeley started working on their own version of Unix, based on AT&T's. This was called "Berkeley Software Development" or BSD for short. The licence for its original parts became known as the BSD Licence (or BSDL or even "BSD" for short) and according to its popular distribution was public-domain-like in the sense that it allowed free modification, redistribution, and conversion of derived code to any different licence.
The original BSD licence had an "advertising clause" that required the one who distributes or modify the code to advertise its use by the copyrights holder. This clause was later deamed as undesirable, and non-GPL-compatible by the Free Software Foundation due to the proliferation of people that require attribution. Therefore, it is now recommended to use the so-called "Modified BSD Licence" with 3-clauses or the further modified one with 2-clauses, which are both GPL-compatible.

The BSD licence has proved to be popular for other software written for UNIX-like operating systems (and open-source software in general). Later on, several variations on this licence were initiated and also become popular.

section.title: The GNU Project and the Creation of the GPL Licence
section.para: In 27 September 1983, Richard M. Stallman (RMS) announced the GNU project (by writing the so-called "GNU Manifesto") aim of creating a new operating that would be entirely "free software", where free is as in "free speech", rather than as in gratis goods. From what I understood based on what Bruce Perens said, what he meant "free software" was at the time not conclusively defined, and that the so-called "Free Software Definition" is a much more recent document, that aimed to provide an anti-thesis to the open-source definition.

Stallman opted against using the BSD licence for the original software created by the GNU project and instead phrased his own more restrictive licence entitled the "GNU General Public License" (or GPL for short), and used it for GNU's software.

The GPL is a relatively complex licence with many fine points. I admit that I did not fully understand version 2.0 of the GPL back when I tried to read it, and know what I know about it by reading knowledgable sources.
Here are the main points about it:

listitem.para: Copyleft - making sure that derived work that are distributed to the outside includes the source and is distributed under the same licence. Note that this does not apply to modifications done for internal or private use.
Restrictive Integration by Other Code bases - GPL code can only be linked against code with free software licences that match some criteria. This property has been recently referred to as "viral".

Despite the first item, GPLed software can be made to run on operating systems and other platforms, whose licences are not incopmatible with itself, including with proprietary, or even binary-only software.

section.para: The GNU Project began to work on software programs and libraries to replace or complement, existing ones in the proprietary UNIX world, and most of them were placed under the GPL. The GPL was adopted for other software released on the Internet and elsewhere for Unix and non-Unix operating systems, but some people still released software under public-domain-like licences, such as the BSDL, the licence of the MIT X Window System (so-called MITL, MIT, X11L or X11) and the pure Public Domain.

This co-existence of the GPL and Public-Domain-like licences still exist to this very day. One should note that some software released for UNIX-like OSes, along with its source, have carried different or even non-free-as-in-speech/non-open-source licences altogether.
